page.title: 01Land Around Glasserton
page.content: This land is characterised by a large estate with farm, church, villae and parkland. To the south lies the cliffs overlooking the Irish Sea. The cliffs are craggy and crumbling with deep erosions. The tops are coverd with heather and thistles. Inland is dry waled and grazed by airy cattle. An Ayeshire bull is used to serve the pure Ayeshire herd so it is unlikely tha he farm employs artificial insemination to impregnae the cows A.I. is preferential as dairy bulls tens to be aggressive. The Estate has many rhododendroms bushes between horse chestnut, ash and oak trees. The church had plain glass windows not stained as is usual. In the churhyard lies a mausoleum, containing the graves of the local lords of the manor, and the family crest engraved in stone. The village of Glasseton
